results.title: New weapons against crime
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom, Burton Benjamin and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Demonstrates the application of modern technology to combat crime. Shows uses of computers, voice prints, olefactronics to identify odours, video tape to record crimes, electronic eavesdropping devices, and chemicals to restrain violence.

results.title: A Circle of love
results.creator_credit: Peter Poor, Isaac Kleinerman, CBS News and West Coast Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
A group of college students get together in a “circle of love”, ie an “encounter group” to improve interpersonal relationships. Comprises highlights from several sessions in which six students, who have never met before, react to taped instructions from a behavioural research institute. Participants learn to express their real feelings about themselves and their fellow students, and learn to overcome anxieties and shyness in the presence of others. Reporter: Walter Cronkite
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Poor, Isaac Kleinerman, CBS News and West Coast Productions

results.title: Incredible voyage
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin, Isaac Kleinerman, CBS News and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Explores the inside of the human body using an endoscope, a viewing system packaged in a rod, used together with a microscope, x-ray and time-lapse photography. Discusses the medical use of the technique. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Medical electronics
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Donald, Isaac Kleinerman and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Shows how technology is helping doctors in the three problem areas of time, training and techniques. The use of electronic diagnostic equipment and information retrieval systems, the training methods which allow students to practice on mock-ups of a patient can now overcome many problems. Fibre optics, pressurized operating rooms, and freezing of diseased tissue are among the many treatment techniques described. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Communications explosion
results.creator_credit: James B. Faichney, Isaac Kleinerman and Columbia Briadcasting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Probable future communication methods and systems, emphasising use of computers. Some experimental devices are shown illustrating verbal computer input and output.

results.title: A Chronic problem
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Scott, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Discussion in bioethics”.
One of a series of short, open-ended dramas designed to stimulate discussion of values and ethics in relation to modern medical technology. This film considers the chronic patient’s right to quality care, and the acutely ill patient’s right to a hospital bed. Jean is suffering from multiple sclerosis and is almost completely paralyzed. It seems that the only ones who care about her are the nurses. With the arrival of a patient in need of an operation, it becomes apparent that chronic patients have little priority.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cynthia Scott, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Cities of the future
results.creator_credit: Gordon Hyatt, Isaac Kleinerman and CBS
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Discusses radical approaches to town planning, showing various concepts. The totally planned new city, Brasilia; incorporation of historic elements as in Philadelphia; pedestrian areas in Miami and Montreal; planned residential extensions; and suggested new construction methods. Exciting architectural ideas include: weather-proofed cities, mega-structures surrounded by green-belts, multi-level cities and floating cities. Features some animated scenes. Narrated by Walter Cronkite and animated by John Hubley.

results.title: Who should decide?
results.creator_credit: Beverly Shaffer, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Discussion in bioethics”.
One of a series of short, open-ended dramas designed to stimulate discussion of values and ethics in relation to modern medical technology. This film deals with questions arising from advances in pre-natal diagnosis. Joanne, a victim of spina bifida, discovers that her unborn child has the same disease. A decision whether to terminate the pregnancy must be reached quickly. When her husband says that all he ever wanted was “a normal baby,” Joanne counters with “What is normal?”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Beverly Shaffer, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada
